answer_html: Hence the value of d can be chosen to be \(\displaystyle d = 109\) since \(\displaystyle 1189(109) \equiv 1 \mod{\phi(1271)}\).
answer_latex:
Hence the value of \emph{d} can be chosen to be $\displaystyle d = 109$
since $\displaystyle 1189(109) \equiv 1 \mod{\phi(1271)}$.
hints_html: Euclidean algorithm to the rescue! Do this with the number \(\displaystyle \phi(n)\) and 1189 and then back substitute.
hints_latex:
Euclidean algorithm to the rescue! Do this with the number
$\displaystyle \phi(n)$ and 1189 and then back substitute.
hints_raw: Euclidean algorithm to the rescue! Do this with the number <math> \displaystyle \phi(n)</math> and 1189 and then back substitute.
question: 5 (b)
sols_html:
We use the Euclidean algorithm to find an inverse. We do this with the numbers 1189 and

\(\displaystyle \phi(n) = \phi(1271) = \phi(31)\phi(41) = 30\cdot 40 = 1200\).

This gives

\[\begin{aligned} 1200 &= 1189(1) + 11\\ 1189 &= 11(108) + 1\end{aligned}\]

and back substituting gives

\[\begin{aligned} 1 &= 1189 - 11(108)\\ 1 &= 1189 - (1200-1189(1))(108)\\ 1 &= 1189(109) - 1200(108)\end{aligned}\]

Hence the value of d can be chosen to be \(\displaystyle d = 109\) since \(\displaystyle 1189(109) \equiv 1 \mod{\phi(1271)}\).
sols_latex:
We use the Euclidean algorithm to find an inverse. We do this with the
numbers 1189 and

$\displaystyle \phi(n) = \phi(1271) = \phi(31)\phi(41) = 30\cdot 40 = 1200$.

This gives

\begin{align*}
1200 &= 1189(1) + 11\\
1189 &= 11(108) + 1
\end{align*}

and back substituting gives

\begin{align*}
1 &= 1189 - 11(108)\\
1 &= 1189 - (1200-1189(1))(108)\\
1 &= 1189(109) - 1200(108)
\end{align*}

Hence the value of \emph{d} can be chosen to be $\displaystyle d = 109$
since $\displaystyle 1189(109) \equiv 1 \mod{\phi(1271)}$.
sols_raw:
We use the Euclidean algorithm to find an inverse. We do this with the numbers 1189 and

<math> \displaystyle \phi(n) = \phi(1271) = \phi(31)\phi(41) = 30\cdot 40 = 1200</math>. 

This gives

<math> \displaystyle 
\begin{align}
1200 &= 1189(1) + 11\\
1189 &= 11(108) + 1
\end{align}
</math>

and back substituting gives

<math> \displaystyle 
\begin{align}
1 &= 1189 - 11(108)\\
1 &= 1189 - (1200-1189(1))(108)\\
1 &= 1189(109) - 1200(108)\\
\end{align}
</math>

Hence the value of ''d'' can be chosen to be <math> \displaystyle d = 109</math> since <math> \displaystyle 1189(109) \equiv 1 \mod{\phi(1271)}</math>.
statement_html:
Alice wants Bob to send her a secret integer P between 0 and 1250 using RSA encryption with key \(\displaystyle (e, n) = (1189, 1271)\) (so the exponent is 1189 and the modulus is 1271, it is way too small to be really secure, but basic RSA encryption and decryption methods still work of course).

(b) To obtain P from C, Alice first computes an inverse \(\displaystyle d \in \mathbb{Z}\) of e modulo \(\displaystyle \phi(n)\), since she created the key, she knows that \(\displaystyle 1271 = 31 \cdot 41\) (in fact, the prime factorization of n can easily be found since it is so small). Compute such a d.
statement_latex:
Alice wants Bob to send her a secret integer \emph{P} between 0 and 1250
using RSA encryption with key $\displaystyle (e, n) = (1189, 1271)$ (so
the exponent is 1189 and the modulus is 1271, it is way too small to be
really secure, but basic RSA encryption and decryption methods still
work of course).

\textbf{(b)} To obtain \emph{P} from \emph{C}, Alice first computes an
inverse $\displaystyle d \in \mathbb{Z}$ of \emph{e} modulo
$\displaystyle \phi(n)$, since she created the key, she knows that
$\displaystyle 1271 = 31 \cdot 41$ (in fact, the prime factorization of
n can easily be found since it is so small). Compute such a \emph{d}.
statement_raw:
Alice wants Bob to send her a secret integer ''P'' between 0 and 1250 using RSA encryption with key <math> \displaystyle (e, n) = (1189, 1271)</math> (so the exponent is 1189 and the modulus is 1271, it is way too small to be really secure, but basic RSA encryption and decryption methods still work of course).

'''(b)''' To obtain ''P'' from ''C'', Alice first computes an inverse <math> \displaystyle d \in \mathbb{Z}</math> of ''e'' modulo <math> \displaystyle \phi(n)</math>, since she created the key, she knows that <math> \displaystyle 1271 = 31 \cdot 41</math> (in fact, the prime factorization of n can easily be found since it is so small). Compute such a ''d''.
